perturbation.original_text: The nature of relationship between the Parties is that of two independent contractor's working together to achieve common goals. There is no payment or compensation contemplated under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: The nature of relationship between the Parties is that of two workers collaborating together to achieve common goals. There is no payment or compensation contemplated under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'independent contractor' is replaced with 'workers', which creates ambiguity regarding the actual relationship. The term 'worker' is broader and could imply an employer-employee relationship, conflicting with the stated intention of an independent contractor arrangement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: US Labor Law, specifically regarding the definition of independent contractor vs. employee.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement and its application and interpretation will be governed exclusively by its terms and the laws of the State of Nevada (USA), and excluding any conflicts of law provisions which would require the application of any law other than Nevada.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement and its application and interpretation will be governed primarily by its terms and secondarily by the laws of the State of Nevada (USA), and including any conflicts of law provisions which would require the application of any law other than Nevada.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'exclusively' to 'primarily' introduces uncertainty about the governing law. The added phrase about including conflicts of law further complicates the legal framework. Nevada law requires contracts to state which jurisdiction takes precedence in legal disagreements. This change undermines the contract's enforceability by creating ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Nevada state law regarding contract law and choice of law provisions.

perturbation.original_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) five (5) business days after being sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, (c) when dispatched by electronic facsimile transmission (with confirmation of successful transmission), or (d) one (1) business day after having been dispatched by an internationally recognized overnight courier service, in each case to the appropriate Party at the address or facsimile number specified below:
perturbation.changed_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) at least five (5) business days after being sent by regular mail, (c) when sent by electronic facsimile transmission, or (d) sometime after having been dispatched by a courier service, in each case to the appropriate Party at the address or facsimile number specified below:
perturbation.explanation: The original text precisely defines the methods of providing notice and their effective dates. By replacing 'registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid' with 'regular mail' and removing other specifics such as 'confirmation of successful transmission' and changing 'one (1) business day after' to 'sometime after' introduces uncertainty about the validity and timing of notices, potentially violating standard contract law requirements for adequate notice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles regarding adequate notice and methods of communication.
